div.p: When I was in London, I reproached my fellow countrymen who had been in Zurich for being forgetful of you and never writing to you: some were ashamed, others even regretted their deep silence.
But I hope they have now written and will write more diligently in the future.
Foxe has written a huge volume about the English martyrs, and it is in English: it was published four days before Easter.
Even the papists are now beginning to detest the cruelty of the arch-papists.
Six or seven were condemned around the beginning of Lent, charged with treason; but the queen's clemency still allows them to live in the Tower of London.
Two of them were called Pole, namely relatives of Cardinal Pole.

The Earl of Huntly, one of the chief nobles of Scotland and a notable papist, incited by the counsel of Guise, was planning to shed the blood of the pious in Scotland, as Guise did in France, and there was a great conspiracy of many seditious people; and undoubtedly the same tumult and indeed bloodshed would have occurred in Scotland as in France, had their attempts not been discovered in time by the grace of God.
Some were killed in battle, among whom was one of Huntly's sons, another son was beheaded along with some others.
Huntly himself was being led to prison; but on the way, he fell backward from his horse and died with a broken neck.
It is uncertain whether this happened by accident or on purpose.
I wrote to you about the cross, candles, and candlesticks taken from the queen's chapel; but shortly after, they were brought back, to the great sorrow of the pious.
The candles, which were previously lit daily, are now not at all. Tepidity in some greatly hinders the course of the gospel.
From the heart, I wish well to all the people of Zurich, whom you should greet in my name, and especially your excellent wife, sons, daughters, etc.
Your John Parkhurst, Bishop of Norwich.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, in Zurich.
